Award.AwardTitle: Robotics and E-Textiles Backpacks for Family Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Libraries serve vital roles in communities not only for access to print media but also family programming and access to the internet. Because of their widespread local presence in communities and the diverse communities served, libraries are well-positioned to address inequalities in access to technology, family programming, and spaces for collaboration. Science centers, universities, and community centers represent resources that can partner with libraries to create science and technology-related content for delivery to diverse communities. Research has firmly established the link between parent engagement and a broad range of student academic outcomes, including higher student attendance, achievement and graduation rates. A growing body of research in out-of-school science learning is focusing on the rich and varied ways in which families learn science outside of school, including habits of mind, motivation, and identities as scientists. Pilot work showed that backpacks have the potential for youth and parents to take on new roles relative to STEM work, with parents or older siblings taking on roles of lab partners, translators, and even teachers. The Robotics and E-Textiles project will support increased capacity within libraries and community centers to hold robotics workshops for families in their own communities. Libraries and community centers will serve as vehicles through which families engage with robotics and e-textiles, resulting in wider access to Next Generation Science Standards' engineering practices to more people. This Innovations in Development project is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments.

Librarians and community engagement leaders will participate in professional experiences to develop science and technology content and facilitation skills. University researchers in collaboration with project partners will use a design-based research methodology to iteratively design the professional development and backpack programs and to investigate learning processes and outcomes. The Cultural Learning Pathways theoretical model will guide the study of how engagement with robotics/e-textiles experiences can lead to changes in practice, identity, and deeper participation in communities of practice on the part of librarians, youth, and families.

Although collaborations between public libraries and informal science providers are becoming increasingly common, this project will document the process of developing such collaborations and draw insights that may be applied to other contexts. By bringing together traditional and non-traditional community organizations to develop and facilitate STEM learning experiences, this project has the potential for resulting in a new model for a decentralized system of informal STEM education and broadening participation in STEM. Over the life of the project, the number of partner libraries will expand from one to four, and it is anticipated to reach more than 550 families. It is being conducted through a partnership between the University of Washington, the Pacific Science Center, the Seattle Public Libraries, and Red Eagle Soaring, a Native American community youth program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a partnership between the University of Washington, Pacific Science Center, Seattle Public Library, and Native American-serving organizations, including the Na’ah Illahee Fund, Red Eagle Soaring, and the Highline Native Education Program. Together, we co-designed two programs: TechTales (robotics) and TechStyle Tales (e-textiles). Both were designed to engage intergenerational groups of families in storytelling through robotics or e-textiles in community settings, such as libraries, housing communities, and organizations serving Indigenous youth and their families. A major outcome of this project was a set of design principles for designing family-centered engineering learning: (1) all learning is cultural, (2) promote multiple ways of knowing and making, (3) scaffold playful thinking and teaching with your hands and body, (4) learning experiences should grow out of the lives of learners, (5) (re) position family members as developing experts working on authentic projects, (6) support full family engagement and contribution throughout, and (7) broaden "what counts" as STEM using everyday & professional forms. 


All learning is a cultural accomplishment: The project used this framework of design principles to understand families’ learning as they engaged in the workshops. Specifically, we studied the ways in which families drew on their linguistic and cultural repertoires of practice to build their stories within the robotics and e-textiles workshops. Through analyzing families-in-interaction as they constructed dioramas with robotics that told their family stories, we explored how cultivating consequential learning environments (Gutiérrez & Jurow, 2016) in STEM is intimately intertwined with historicity, knowledge systems, and the agentic positioning of learners to design new technologies (Prins, 2002). We found that using storywork (Archibald, 2008) as the design focus of building dioramas created learning environments where computer programming and robotics became dynamic tools towards family-making, collaboration, and the active presencing of Indigenous knowledge systems and cultural practices. Living and interrelating with story and its knowledge systems through making were enactments of Indigenous resurgence in everyday ways (Barajas & Bang, 2018; Corntassel, 2012). We also found that, in a largely Spanish-speaking community setting, families used a variety of translanguaging practices when collaborating and sharing their family stories. We found that, when robotics and engineering learning environments are intentionally designed around intergenerational learning and family storytelling, this invites families to leverage the cultural and linguistic resources from their own cultures, histories, and identities. 

 

Opportunities to explore natural phenomena through robotics: The intertwining of stories with technology allows opportunities for (1) exploring natural phenomena, and (2) opportunities for transformational agency that refuse technological domination. By analyzing case studies of family learning, we see family knowledge being built within everyday practice. In the act of re-creating memories from family stories (campfires, stars twinkling, the solar eclipse) and create certain aesthetic effects within their projects, opportunities open up for families explore those phenomena. For example, in attempting to re-create star’s twinkle by programming an LED light, a father and son discuss the fact that stars don’t really “twinkle” but rather it is the temperature of the air that makes them appear to do so.   Story is therefore a way for families to navigate across knowledge domains—of coding, family knowledge and memories, astronomy (and other disciplines), and design thinking. We also see that stories are ways for families’ refusal to be dominated by perceived limitations of technology as they transform material to re-create their memories from the family story. 

 

Participatory Design Research (PDR): This project engaged librarians, community organizations, families, and university researchers in a process of participatory design research to understand how to design family-centered robotics and e-textiles learning environments that centered family knowledges and practices. In this work, we found that (a) it was crucial within the design team to practice  role re-mediation and porosity within the partnership, meaning that all members of the partnership took on varying roles--university researchers took on roles as facilitators, librarians and community members were researchers and designers, families were both participants and co-designers. This allowed for the emergence of new identities, expertise, and agency to take shape in the design space. We also found  the need to examine what it means to coordinate new initiatives within existing institutional structures and underlying images of and responsibilities related to professional activity (Bell, 2016). Working within both library and community spaces meant coordinating with existing institutional opportunities and constraints, as well as always building towards infrastructuring and re-defining professional roles.
